Welcome to my house!
University of Auckland

The Reading Activity will primarily be used to check a learner's comprehension of a given text. This can be done by asking the learner to reflect on the reading and respond to questions about the reading, or by having them complete some other possibly more physical task based on the reading.

Teachers should keep the following in mind when using this iDevice:

  1. Think about the number of different types of activity planned for your resource that will be visually signalled in the content. Avoid using too many different types or classification of activities otherwise learner may become confused. Usually three or four different types are more than adequate for a teaching resource.
  2. From a visual design perspective, avoid having two iDevices immediately following each other without any text in between. If this is required, rather collapse two questions or events into one iDevice.
  3. Think about activities where the perceived benefit of doing the activity outweighs the time and effort it will take to complete the activity.
Enter the details of the reading including reference details. The referencing style used will depend on the preference of your faculty or department.
What to read

Welcome!

 This is my house and I want to show you all the things that I have.

 Can you tell me what there is in my house? Can you count the objects? Come in!

What to read
In this grammar activity, you will be able to distinguish the use of there is and there are in a house context, as well to apply correctly these terms in an affirmative-negative-interrogative form.
Describe the tasks related to the reading learners should undertake. This helps demonstrate relevance for learners.

What I do have to know?

What to read

Grammar?!  Don't worry! You will learn the grammar during the activity, but you need to know some basic house vocabulary, for example:

  • fridge
  • pillow
  • table
  • living room

Watch this video about house vocabulary so you can remember some words. Repeat the pronunciation!


If you don't remember the words during the activity, relax  . You will see the online dictionary at the end of each section.

The kitchen
University of Auckland

The Reading Activity will primarily be used to check a learner's comprehension of a given text. This can be done by asking the learner to reflect on the reading and respond to questions about the reading, or by having them complete some other possibly more physical task based on the reading.

Teachers should keep the following in mind when using this iDevice:

  1. Think about the number of different types of activity planned for your resource that will be visually signalled in the content. Avoid using too many different types or classification of activities otherwise learner may become confused. Usually three or four different types are more than adequate for a teaching resource.
  2. From a visual design perspective, avoid having two iDevices immediately following each other without any text in between. If this is required, rather collapse two questions or events into one iDevice.

Enter the details of the reading including reference details. The referencing style used will depend on the preference of your faculty or department.
What to read

We are in my kitchen!

Look at my fridge:

 I'm vegetarian, so I have many vegetables.

  -You can say: there are many vegetables in the fridge.

I have only one papaya.

  -You can say: there is one papaya in the fridge.

I have four bananas.

  -You can say: there are four bananas in the fridge.

I have one avocado for my guacamole.

  -You can say: there is one avocado in the fridge. 

We use there is and there are to say that something exists.

Affirmative Sentences

We use there is for singular and there are for plural.

  • There is one sink in the kitchen.
  • There are three apples on the table.
  • There is milk in the fridge.
  • There are many plates in my kitchen.

Contractions

There is = there's.

  • There's a cake in the oven.

     x You cannot contract there are.

  • There are six forks on the table.

Problems with vocabulary?

Use this online dictionary

1. There are  strawberries.
  2. There is a fork.
  3. There is a knife.
  4. There are some flowers.
  5. There is some juice.
  6. There are three slices of bread.
  7. There is some butter on the bread.
If this option is set, each word will be marked as the learner types it rather than all the words being marked the end of the exercise.

Enter the text for the cloze activity in to the cloze field by either pasting text from another source or by typing text directly into the field.

To select words to hide, double click on the word to select it and click on the Hide/Show Word button below.

More than one possible answer can be defined enclosing them with pipes (|). I.e.: |dog|cat|bird|

If left unchecked a small number of spelling and capitalization errors will be accepted. If checked only an exact match in spelling and capitalization will be accepted.

For example: If the correct answer is Elephant then both elephant and Eliphant will be judged "close enough" by the algorithm as it only has one letter wrong, even if "Check Capitalization" is on.

If capitalization checking is off in the above example, the lowercase e will not be considered a mistake and eliphant will also be accepted.

If both "Strict Marking" and "Check Capitalization" are set, the only correct answer is "Elephant". If only "Strict Marking" is checked and "Check Capitalization" is not, "elephant" will also be accepted.

1. There are  strawberries.
  2. There is a fork.
  3. There is a knife.
  4. There are some flowers.
  5. There is some juice.
  6. There are three slices of bread.
  7. There is some butter on the bread.

Cloze exercises are texts or sentences where students must fill in missing words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Select words in the text thatare key to understanding the concepts. Thesewill probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs.Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test vocabulary knowledge

Write a text using the target vocabulary. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Highlight the target words in the text. Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test word formation/grammar:

Write a text using the target forms. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Remember that the goal is not vocabulary knowledge, so the core meanings of the stem words should be well known to the students.

Highlight the target words in the text. Provide alternatives with the same word stem, but different affixes. It is a good idea to get a colleague to test the test/exercise to make sure there are no surprises!
Enter any feedback you wish to provide the learner with-in the feedback field. This field can be left blank.

• We use THERE IS for SINGULAR nouns.
  • We use THERE ARE for PLURAL nouns.
The bathroom
University of Auckland

The Reading Activity will primarily be used to check a learner's comprehension of a given text. This can be done by asking the learner to reflect on the reading and respond to questions about the reading, or by having them complete some other possibly more physical task based on the reading.

Teachers should keep the following in mind when using this iDevice:

  1. Think about the number of different types of activity planned for your resource that will be visually signalled in the content. Avoid using too many different types or classification of activities otherwise learner may become confused. Usually three or four different types are more than adequate for a teaching resource.
  2. From a visual design perspective, avoid having two iDevices immediately following each other without any text in between. If this is required, rather collapse two questions or events into one iDevice.
  3. Think about activities where the perceived benefit of doing the activity outweighs the time and effort it will take to complete the activity.
Enter the details of the reading including reference details. The referencing style used will depend on the preference of your faculty or department.
What to read

Now, we are in my bathroom!

Can you identify some of the objects in the picture?

  • There are some plants.
  • There is one toilet.
  • There is a mirror. 
  • There are two white towels.

Etc, etc.

There are many objects in my bathroom, but there isn't a chair.

There isn't a toothpaste. 

There aren't any toothbrushes in my bathroom.

I can mention the things that exist in my bathroom, and mention the things that DON'T.

Negative Form

The negative is formed by putting not after is or are:

  • There is not a soap in the shower.
  • There are not clean towels.

Contractions

  • There is not = There isn't
  • There are not = There aren't

There aren't with ANY

When we want to indicate that a ZERO QUANTITY of something we use there aren't any.

  • There aren't any rolls of toilet paper.
  • There isn't any shampoo in the shower.

Enter any feedback you wish to provide to the learner. This field may be left blank. if this field is left blank default feedback will be provided.
A hint may be provided to assist the learner in answering the question.

True/false questions present a statement where the learner must decide if the statement is true. This type of question works well for factual information and information that lends itself to either/or responses.
Type the question stem. The question should be clear and unambiguous. Avoid negative premises as these can tend to be ambiguous.
Escriba la pregunta. La pregunta debe ser clara y no ambigua. Evite las premisas negativas ya que esta tienden a ser ambiguas.
1. There aren't two green towels.

Introduzca la retroalimentación que quiere que vean los estudiantes después de haber intentado completar la actividad. Este campo se puede dejar vacío. Si este campo está vacío se ofrecerá la retroalimentación por defecto.
TRUE. There is only one green towel.
Se puede proporcionar una pista para ayudar al estudiante a responder la pregunta.
Escriba la pregunta. La pregunta debe ser clara y no ambigua. Evite las premisas negativas ya que esta tienden a ser ambiguas.
2. There aren't two toilets. There is one.

Introduzca la retroalimentación que quiere que vean los estudiantes después de haber intentado completar la actividad. Este campo se puede dejar vacío. Si este campo está vacío se ofrecerá la retroalimentación por defecto.
TRUE. There is only one toilet.
Se puede proporcionar una pista para ayudar al estudiante a responder la pregunta.
Escriba la pregunta. La pregunta debe ser clara y no ambigua. Evite las premisas negativas ya que esta tienden a ser ambiguas.
3. There isn't a bathtub.

Introduzca la retroalimentación que quiere que vean los estudiantes después de haber intentado completar la actividad. Este campo se puede dejar vacío. Si este campo está vacío se ofrecerá la retroalimentación por defecto.
FALSE. There is a bathtub.
Se puede proporcionar una pista para ayudar al estudiante a responder la pregunta.
Escriba la pregunta. La pregunta debe ser clara y no ambigua. Evite las premisas negativas ya que esta tienden a ser ambiguas.
4. There aren't any flowers.

Introduzca la retroalimentación que quiere que vean los estudiantes después de haber intentado completar la actividad. Este campo se puede dejar vacío. Si este campo está vacío se ofrecerá la retroalimentación por defecto.
FALSE. There are some flowers.
Se puede proporcionar una pista para ayudar al estudiante a responder la pregunta.
Escriba la pregunta. La pregunta debe ser clara y no ambigua. Evite las premisas negativas ya que esta tienden a ser ambiguas.
5. There is a mirror.

Introduzca la retroalimentación que quiere que vean los estudiantes después de haber intentado completar la actividad. Este campo se puede dejar vacío. Si este campo está vacío se ofrecerá la retroalimentación por defecto.
TRUE. There is only one mirror.
Se puede proporcionar una pista para ayudar al estudiante a responder la pregunta.

The Reading Activity will primarily be used to check a learner's comprehension of a given text. This can be done by asking the learner to reflect on the reading and respond to questions about the reading, or by having them complete some other possibly more physical task based on the reading.

  2. From a visual design perspective, avoid having two iDevices immediately following each other without any text in between. If this is required, rather collapse two questions or events into one iDevice.

What to read

And finally... my bedroom!

Look at the picture and the following questions.

Is there a bed?

Yes, there is.

Are there any pillows on the bed?

Yes, there are.

Is there a cookie next to the coffee?

No, there isn't.

Are there any family photographs?

No, there aren't.

Questions

We form questions using is / are in front of there (the opposite position) 

We use any with plural questions and uncountable nouns.

  • Is there any music in the bedroom? - music is an uncountable noun.
  • Are there any jeans in the closet? - jeans is a plural noun.

We use there is / are in short answers.

  • Is there a dog in the bedroom? - No, there isn't.
  • Are there any dogs in the bedroom? - No, there aren't.
  • Is there an air-conditioner? - No, there isn't.
  • Are there any lights in the bedroom? - Yes, there are.

Watch this video so you can practice the pronunciation of questions and answers.

Cloze exercises are texts or sentences where students must fill in missing words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.

  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Select words in the text thatare key to understanding the concepts. Thesewill probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs.Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

Write a text using the target vocabulary. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Highlight the target words in the text. Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

What to read

The tour around my house is finished!

And now you can use correctly there is and there are.

  • Write 6 sentences describing the objects that EXIST or DO NOT EXIST in your own house, for example:

There are two bedrooms in my house./There isn't a garden in my house.

Check your sentences:

1. Be sure that you used THERE IS/ISN'T or THERE ARE/AREN'T

2. Check the plural nouns with ARE and singulars with IS.

3. Use a dictionary to check your vocabulary and ortography.

  • Did you like this activity? In your notebook, write a short reflection about this activity.

I liked... I learned... It was difficult to...

  • Create a glossary with all the new words you learned in this activity.

Activity validation
Validate your activity

Duration:
10:00

To finish this activity you will answer a validation quiz. It is important to consider these things:

      1. To get this activity validated, you must score at least 80% in this quiz.

      2. In order not to lose points, it is important to check not only your answer but your spelling too.

What to read

• English Grammar Today. (s.f.) There is, there’s and there are. Available on: https://dictionary.cambridge.org/es/gramatica/gramatica-britanica/there-is-there-s-and-there-are
